steps.title: Lock your wheelchair’s brakes to stop it from rolling away.
steps.content: Lock your wheelchair’s brakes to stop it from rolling away. Typically, the brakes are activated by engaging the small levers located in front of the rear wheels. Push the levers toward the wheels to engage the brakes. Be sure to pull up on the levers away from the wheels to activate the brakes.

steps.title: Remove the large rear wheels.
steps.content: Remove the large rear wheels. On most models, there is a locking pin located above the center of the wheel. Press down on the pin and hold it in place. While pressing the pin down, grab the wheel and pull it outward off of the chair. Refer to the manufacturer's instructions if your model doesn't have a pin.

steps.title: Flip the wheelchair’s footplates to the side.
steps.content: Flip the wheelchair’s footplates to the side. The footplates are located in front of the front wheels. Start by grabbing the left footplate and gently push it to the left. Now, grab the right one and gently push it to the right. Grab the footplates by the front for the best grip.

steps.title: Move the armrests to the side if your chair has any.
steps.content: Move the armrests to the side if your chair has any. Start by gently moving the left armrest to the left. Afterward, move the right armrest to the right. Skip this step if your wheelchair doesn't have armrests.

steps.title: Pull upward on the brace to unlock it.
steps.content: Pull upward on the brace to unlock it. Grab the brace at the middle and firmly pull it upward. This will unlock it and get the chair ready for folding. Skip this step if your chair doesn’t have a brace.

steps.title: Grab the wheelchair’s seat from the front and back.
steps.content: Grab the wheelchair’s seat from the front and back. Start by standing directly in front of your wheelchair. Now, put one hand flat against the front of the seat and the other flat against the back. [1] X Research source Be sure to hold the seat firmly.

steps.title: Lift the seat slowly to the middle to fold the wheelchair.
steps.content: Lift the seat slowly to the middle to fold the wheelchair. With each hand on one side of the seat, lift up the seat while maintaining a firm grip on the chair. As you lift the seat, the chair will begin to fold together as the wheels move closer together. Continue closing the chair until the seat is completely raised in the middle. [2] X Research source If your chair isn’t moving up, make sure that you’re applying enough pressure to the seat. Keep your fingers away from the folding mechanism and any moving parts of the wheelchair as you fold it.

steps.title: Undo the wheelchair's locking bar.
steps.content: Undo the wheelchair's locking bar. The locking bar typically extends from the frame to the cross-braces—the x-shaped strut support between the side frames. Pull the bar out to unlock it and prepare your wheelchair for unfolding. Check the manufacturer's instructions if you're having trouble locating and undoing the locking bar, as there are variations between models.

steps.title: Stand the wheelchair on its front casters.
steps.content: Stand the wheelchair on its front casters. The front casters are the small front wheels. Be sure to find a flat, level surface for your chair to make the process easier. Hold the wheelchair steady as it stands on its front casters.

steps.title: Press down on one of the wheelchair's seat tubes.
steps.content: Press down on one of the wheelchair's seat tubes. Start by gripping one of the back handles of the chair—these are the ones used to guide it from behind. Now, while maintaining your grip, push down on the seat's tube handles opposite to the back handle. [3] X Research source Be sure to press down firmly but slowly and guide the chair open as it unfolds. Push down on the seat tubes after unfolding the chair to double-check that it's completely unfolded.

steps.title: Lock the rear wheel brace.
steps.content: Lock the rear wheel brace. Locate the metal bar that runs parallel to the diameter of the rear wheel. Now, press down on it firmly until you hear it lock into place. Give the brace a jiggle after pressing down on the metal bar to make sure it's properly locked. Keep your fingers free of the folding mechanism as you unfold the chair.

steps.title: Engage the wheelchair's wheel locks.
steps.content: Engage the wheelchair's wheel locks. Locate the locks along the 2 primary wheels and engage them by pressing them in the designated direction. Check the manufacturer's instructions for the specific procedure if you're having trouble.

steps.title: Install large rear wheels if your wheelchair is a convertible.
steps.content: Install large rear wheels if your wheelchair is a convertible. Grab the frame at the rear legs. Now, depress the button located on the quick release axle and push the wheel axle into the axle housing on the frame until you hear a click. [4] X Research source Always pull the wheel in the opposite direction of the attachment.

steps.title: Remove detachable parts of the chair before storing it.
steps.content: Remove detachable parts of the chair before storing it. This includes side guards, seat cushions, cup holders, footrests, bags, and lighting kits. Store the parts in a closet with the chair or—if you're flying—into an overhead bin. Always remove detachable parts when you're flying to prevent damage to your chair.

steps.title: Store your wheelchair in the wheelchair closet or cargo hold if you're flying.
steps.content: Store your wheelchair in the wheelchair closet or cargo hold if you're flying. Typically, wheelchairs are stored in a specialized closet—ask about these closets prior to flying. If your wheelchair doesn't fit, it will need to be placed in the airplane's cargo hold. [5] X Research source Remember that access to wheelchair storage closets is given on a first come, first served basis, so reserve a spot as early as you can when you're flying.

steps.title: Avoid storage areas with extreme temperatures to keep the battery safe.
steps.content: Avoid storage areas with extreme temperatures to keep the battery safe. Wheelchair batteries are sensitive to extreme temperatures. Be sure to keep your wheelchair stored in a room with a stable temperature range. Always store your wheelchair away from humidity and sunlight. Wheelchairs should be stored in areas with temperatures between 20 to 110 °F (−7 to 43 °C).
